Operation 'DeleteSpamReports' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. While the description explains the operation well, it lacks explicit information about the response/return value and could better structure the side effects. Added clarity about what the operation returns (success confirmation with no body) and reorganized side effects information for better AI agent understanding of the consequences of this destructive operation.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete your spam reports.**

Deleting a spam report will remove the suppression, meaning email will once again be sent to the previously suppressed address. This should be avoided unless a recipient indicates they wish to receive email from you again. You can use our [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) to deliver messages to otherwise suppressed addresses when exceptions are required.

There are two options for deleting spam reports: 

1. You can delete all spam reports by setting the `delete_all` field to `true` in the request body.
2. You can delete a list of select spam reports by specifying the email addresses in the `emails` array of the request body.
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint allows you to delete spam report suppressions.**

Deleting a spam report removes the suppression, allowing email to be sent again to the previously suppressed address. This action should be avoided unless a recipient explicitly requests to receive email from you again.

**Input Options:**
1. Delete all spam reports by setting `delete_all` to `true` in the request body
2. Delete specific spam reports by providing email addresses in the `emails` array

**Side Effects:** Removes suppression status for specified addresses, enabling future email delivery to those recipients. Use [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) for exceptions without removing suppressions.

**Response:** Returns success confirmation. No response body is returned.
data.reasoning: While the description explains the operation well, it lacks explicit information about the response/return value and could better structure the side effects. Added clarity about what the operation returns (success confirmation with no body) and reorganized side effects information for better AI agent understanding of the consequences of this destructive operation.

message: Operation 'GetSpamReport' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details. Original description is too brief and lacks output details. Added information about what the operation returns (spam report object with email and timestamp), clarified that it retrieves suppression status, and explained the path parameter requirement. This helps AI agents understand what data they'll receive and how to use the response.

data.current_description: **This endpoint allows you to retrieve a specific spam report by email address.**
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a specific spam report suppression by email address.**

Provide the email address as a path parameter to retrieve the spam report details for that address. Returns the spam report object containing the email address and timestamp information if the address is suppressed due to spam reports.
data.reasoning: Original description is too brief and lacks output details. Added information about what the operation returns (spam report object with email and timestamp), clarified that it retrieves suppression status, and explained the path parameter requirement. This helps AI agents understand what data they'll receive and how to use the response.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete a specific spam report by email address.**

Deleting a spam report will remove the suppression, meaning email will once again be sent to the previously suppressed address. This should be avoided unless a recipient indicates they wish to receive email from you again. You can use our [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) to deliver messages to otherwise suppressed addresses when exceptions are required.
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint allows you to delete a specific spam report suppression by email address.**

Provide the email address as a path parameter to remove the spam report suppression for that address. Deleting a spam report removes the suppression, allowing email to be sent again to the previously suppressed address.

**Side Effects:** Removes suppression status for the specified address, enabling future email delivery. This action should be avoided unless a recipient explicitly requests to receive email from you again. Use [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) for exceptions without removing suppressions.

**Response:** Returns success confirmation. No response body is returned.
data.reasoning: Description lacks explicit information about the response and could better structure side effects. Added clarity about path parameter usage, what the operation returns (success confirmation), and reorganized side effects for better AI agent understanding of this destructive operation's consequences.

message: Operation 'ListGlobalSuppression' has semantic quality issues: inconsistent_terminology. The description uses 'globally suppressed' but the API context defines global suppressions as addresses that have been 'unsubscribed from all emails.' The endpoint path uses 'unsubscribes' which aligns with the domain terminology. Added clarification that global suppressions represent unsubscribes from all messages for consistency with API documentation and improved AI agent understanding of the distinction between global suppressions and other suppression types.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a paginated list of all email address that are globally suppressed.**

You can use the `limit` query parameter to set the page size. If your list contains more items than the page size permits, you can make multiple requests. Use the `offset` query parameter to control the position in the list from which to start retrieving additional items.
data.description_suggestion:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a paginated list of all email addresses that are globally unsubscribed.**

Global suppressions represent addresses that have unsubscribed from all emails. You can use the `limit` query parameter to set the page size. If your list contains more items than the page size permits, you can make multiple requests. Use the `offset` query parameter to control the position in the list from which to start retrieving additional items.
data.reasoning: The description uses 'globally suppressed' but the API context defines global suppressions as addresses that have been 'unsubscribed from all emails.' The endpoint path uses 'unsubscribes' which aligns with the domain terminology. Added clarification that global suppressions represent unsubscribes from all messages for consistency with API documentation and improved AI agent understanding of the distinction between global suppressions and other suppression types.

message: Operation 'DeleteSuppressionBounces' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Original summary 'Delete bounces' is too vague and doesn't clarify the suppression context. Description lacks information about the response/return value. Enhanced summary specifies the action and domain context. Enhanced description clarifies the two deletion modes, the mutual exclusivity constraint, and adds expected output information for better AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description:
This endpoint allows you to delete all emails on your bounces list.

There are two options for deleting bounced emails: 

1. You can delete all bounced emails by setting `delete_all` to `true` in the request body. 
2. You can delete a selection of bounced emails by specifying the email addresses in the `emails` array of the request body. 

**WARNING:** You can not have both `emails` and `delete_all` set.
data.summary_suggestion: Delete bounced emails from suppression list
data.description_suggestion: Removes email addresses from your bounce suppression list. Supports two deletion modes: (1) delete all bounced emails by setting `delete_all` to `true`, or (2) delete specific emails by providing an array of email addresses in the `emails` field. Note: `emails` and `delete_all` cannot both be set. Returns a success response indicating the number of addresses removed.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Delete bounces' is too vague and doesn't clarify the suppression context. Description lacks information about the response/return value. Enhanced summary specifies the action and domain context. Enhanced description clarifies the two deletion modes, the mutual exclusivity constraint, and adds expected output information for better AI agent interpretability.

message: Operation 'ListSuppressionBouncesClassifications' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_context, missing_output_details. Original summary lacks specificity about the time-series aspect. Description doesn't explain what data is returned or how to interpret results. Enhanced summary clarifies the grouping and ordering. Enhanced description specifies response format options, return value structure, and use case context to help AI agents understand when and how to use this operation.

data.current_description: This endpoint will return the total number of bounces by classification in descending order for each day. You can retrieve the bounce classification totals in CSV format by specifying `"text/csv"` in the Accept header.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve bounce totals by classification and day
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves aggregated bounce statistics grouped by classification type, with results ordered by count in descending order for each day. Supports multiple response formats: JSON (default) or CSV format (specify `"text/csv"` in the Accept header). Returns an array of bounce classification objects containing classification type, count, and date information. Useful for analyzing bounce patterns and trends over time.
data.reasoning: Original summary lacks specificity about the time-series aspect. Description doesn't explain what data is returned or how to interpret results. Enhanced summary clarifies the grouping and ordering. Enhanced description specifies response format options, return value structure, and use case context to help AI agents understand when and how to use this operation.

message: Operation 'GetSuppressionBouncesClassifications' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, unclear_purpose, missing_output_details. Original summary is confusing with 'by domain stats' which is not clearly explained in the description. The purpose of the classification parameter is unclear. Enhanced summary clarifies that this retrieves data for a specific classification. Enhanced description specifies the required path parameter, response formats, return value structure, and use case context for better AI agent interpretability.

data.current_summary: Retrieve bounce classification over time by domain stats
data.current_description: This endpoint will return the number of bounces for the classification specified in descending order for each day. You can retrieve the bounce classification totals in CSV format by specifying `"text/csv"` in the Accept header.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve bounce statistics for a specific classification
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves bounce statistics for a specific bounce classification type, with results ordered by count in descending order for each day. Supports multiple response formats: JSON (default) or CSV format (specify `"text/csv"` in the Accept header). Returns time-series data showing bounce counts by classification and date. Requires the classification type as a path parameter. Useful for analyzing bounce patterns for a specific classification category over time.
data.reasoning: Original summary is confusing with 'by domain stats' which is not clearly explained in the description. The purpose of the classification parameter is unclear. Enhanced summary clarifies that this retrieves data for a specific classification. Enhanced description specifies the required path parameter, response formats, return value structure, and use case context for better AI agent interpretability.

message: Operation 'GetGlobalSuppression' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Original summary 'Retrieve a Global Suppression' is vague and doesn't clarify the lookup/verification purpose. Description is verbose and could be more concise. Improved summary emphasizes the verification action. Improved description clarifies the dual return states (suppressed vs. not suppressed) and explains the practical use case for AI agents to understand when to call this operation.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a global suppression. You can also use this endpoint to confirm if an email address is already globally suppresed.**

If the email address you include in the URL path parameter `{email}` is already globally suppressed, the response will include that email address. If the address you enter for `{email}` is not globally suppressed, an empty JSON object `{}` will be returned.
data.summary_suggestion: Check if email address is globally suppressed
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the global suppression status for a specific email address. Returns the email address object if it is globally suppressed, or an empty JSON object `{}` if the address is not suppressed. Use this endpoint to verify whether an email address has been globally suppressed from all SendGrid messages.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Retrieve a Global Suppression' is vague and doesn't clarify the lookup/verification purpose. Description is verbose and could be more concise. Improved summary emphasizes the verification action. Improved description clarifies the dual return states (suppressed vs. not suppressed) and explains the practical use case for AI agents to understand when to call this operation.

message: Operation 'DeleteGlobalSuppression' has semantic quality issues: missing_side_effects, missing_output_details. Summary is clear and action-oriented. However, description contains confusing language ('Deleting a suppression group' vs. deleting an address) and lacks clarity about the return response. Improved description clarifies the operation removes a single address (not a group), emphasizes the business context (recipient consent), and specifies the expected HTTP response for AI agent clarity.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to remove an email address from the global suppressions group.**

Deleting a suppression group will remove the suppression, meaning email will once again be sent to the previously suppressed addresses. This should be avoided unless a recipient indicates they wish to receive email from you again. You can use our [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) to deliver messages to otherwise suppressed addresses when exceptions are required.
data.description_suggestion: Removes an email address from the global suppressions group, allowing emails to be sent to that address again. This operation should only be performed if the recipient has explicitly requested to receive emails. After deletion, the address will no longer be filtered from sends. Returns a 204 No Content response on successful deletion.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and action-oriented. However, description contains confusing language ('Deleting a suppression group' vs. deleting an address) and lacks clarity about the return response. Improved description clarifies the operation removes a single address (not a group), emphasizes the business context (recipient consent), and specifies the expected HTTP response for AI agent clarity.

message: Operation 'DeleteInvalidEmails' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Summary 'Delete invalid emails' is too generic and doesn't clarify the scope (all vs. specific). Description lacks clarity about mutually exclusive options and missing return response information. Improved summary specifies the action target. Improved description clarifies the two modes are mutually exclusive, specifies the expected HTTP response, and helps AI agents understand the request structure.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to remove email addresses from your invalid email address list.**

There are two options for deleting invalid email addresses: 

1) You can delete all invalid email addresses by setting `delete_all` to true in the request body.
2) You can delete some invalid email addresses by specifying certain addresses in an array in the request body.
data.summary_suggestion: Remove email addresses from invalid email list
data.description_suggestion: Removes one or more email addresses from the invalid email address list. Supports two deletion modes: (1) delete all invalid emails by setting `delete_all` to true, or (2) delete specific addresses by providing an array of email addresses in the request body. Returns a 204 No Content response on successful deletion. Only one deletion mode should be used per request.
data.reasoning: Summary 'Delete invalid emails' is too generic and doesn't clarify the scope (all vs. specific). Description lacks clarity about mutually exclusive options and missing return response information. Improved summary specifies the action target. Improved description clarifies the two modes are mutually exclusive, specifies the expected HTTP response, and helps AI agents understand the request structure.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete all email addresses on your blocks list.**

There are two options for deleting blocked emails: 

1. You can delete all blocked emails by setting `delete_all` to `true` in the request body. 
2. You can delete a selection of blocked emails by specifying the email addresses in the `emails` array of the request body.
data.summary_suggestion: Delete blocked email addresses from blocks list
data.description_suggestion: Delete email addresses from your blocks list. Supports two deletion modes: (1) delete all blocked emails by setting `delete_all` to `true` in the request body, or (2) delete specific blocked emails by providing an array of email addresses in the `emails` field. Returns a success response confirming the deletion. Use this operation to remove blocks and allow email delivery to previously blocked addresses.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic ('Delete blocks' could mean various things). Improved to clarify the action targets blocked email addresses. Description explains the two deletion modes but lacks information about the response and side effects. data.current_summary: Retrieve all suppression groups associated with the user.
data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a list of all suppression groups created by this user.**

This endpoint can also return information for multiple group IDs that you include in your request. To add a group ID to your request, simply append `?id=123456&id=123456`, with the appropriate group IDs.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of all suppression groups (unsubscribe groups) created by the authenticated user. Supports filtering by specific group IDs using query parameters (e.g., ?id=123456&id=789012). Returns an array of suppression group objects, each containing group ID, name, description, and suppression count. Useful for discovering available groups or checking group configurations.

message: Operation 'DeleteAsmGroup' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Summary has inconsistent capitalization. Description buries critical side effects and consequences. Reorganized to clearly state the operation's effects upfront, emphasized the irreversible nature of the action, and clarified the return value. This helps AI agents understand the gravity of the operation and when it's appropriate to use.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete a suppression group.**

If a recipient uses the "one-click unsubscribe" option on an email associated with a deleted group, that recipient will be added to the global suppression list.

Deleting a suppression group will remove the suppression, meaning email will once again be sent to the previously suppressed addresses. This should be avoided unless a recipient indicates they wish to receive email from you again. You can use our [bypass filters](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/index-suppressions/#bypass-suppressions) to deliver messages to otherwise suppressed addresses when exceptions are required.
data.description_suggestion: Deletes a suppression group by its group ID. This operation has significant side effects: all email addresses previously suppressed by this group will be removed from suppression, and emails will resume being sent to those addresses. If recipients use one-click unsubscribe on emails associated with the deleted group, they will be added to the global suppression list instead. This operation should only be performed when recipients have explicitly requested to receive emails again. Returns a 204 No Content response on successful deletion.
data.reasoning: Summary has inconsistent capitalization. Description buries critical side effects and consequences. Reorganized to clearly state the operation's effects upfront, emphasized the irreversible nature of the action, and clarified the return value. This helps AI agents understand the gravity of the operation and when it's appropriate to use.

data.current_summary: Add suppressions to a suppression group
data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to add email addresses to an unsubscribe group.**

If you attempt to add suppressions to a group that has been deleted or does not exist, the suppressions will be added to the global suppressions list.
data.description_suggestion: Adds one or more email addresses to a suppression group by its group ID. Accepts a request body containing an array of email addresses to suppress. Returns a 201 Created response on success. Important side effect: if the specified group has been deleted or does not exist, the email addresses will be added to the global suppression list instead of the target group. This operation prevents emails from being sent to the specified addresses within the group's scope.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear but description lacks input/output details and buries the important side effect. Added clarity about request format (array of emails), return value, and emphasized the fallback behavior to global suppressions. This helps AI agents understand the operation's inputs, outputs, and potential consequences.
